questions.text: A 30yr female comes to clinic with pain in the lower abdominal area, on USG the deep inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged; infection of the which of the following can be suspected
questions.solution:
Clitoris is drained by Deep Inguinal Lymph node

Ovaries drained by Aortic Lymph nodes

Vagina is drained by Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

Therefore infection in the clitoris might lead to enlarged deep inguinal lymph nodes

Deep inguinal lymph nodes- 4- 5 in number and lie medial to the upper part of femoral vein.

Most proximal node of this group- glans of cloquet or rosenmuller, lies in femoral canal.

Vagina- upper one third is drain into external iliac lymph nodes, Middle one third is drain into internal iliac nodes, Lower one third into superficial Inguinal lymphnode.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 1 lower limb Chapter 11 venous and lymphatic drianage page no. 153

Section 2 chapter 31 female reproductive organs page no. 458.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not included in muscles of Perineal body
questions.solution:
Perineal body is the central point of the perineum.

It is a fibromuscular node situated in the median plane, about 1.25 cm in front of the anal margin and close to the bulb of penis.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body A) Two unpaired (i) External anal sphincter 4), (ii) Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal. B) Four paired, (i) Bulbospongiosus muscle 9. A (ii) Superficial transverse perinei, (iii) Deep transversus Perinei), (iv) Levator ani in females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here

The muscles are two superficial transversus perinei, two deep transversus perinei, two pubococcygeus part of levator ani, two bulbospongiosus and single sphincter ani externus and unstriped fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of the anal canal.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 Abdomen and pelvis

Chapter 31 female reporductive organs page no. 454

questions.text: Which of the following movement is not possible with saddle joint
questions.solution:
Saddle variety of synovial joint (because the articular surfaces are concavoconvex).

Articular Surfaces

  1. The distal surface of the trapezium
  2. The proximal surface of the base of the first metacarpal bone.

The articulating surface of trapezium is concave in the sagittal plane and convex in the frontal plane. The concavoconvex nature of the articular surfaces permits a wide range of movements.

There are eight small carpal bones occupying very and small area of the hand. First carpometacarpal joints joint, i.e. joint between trapezium and base of 1st metacarpal is a unique joint. It is of saddle variety and permits a versatile movement of opposition in addition to other movements. This permits the hand to hold things, e.g. doll, pencil, food, bat, etc. Opponens pollicis is specially for opposition.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 1 upper limb

Chapter 10 joints of upper limb Page no 179 and 189.

questions.text: A 56yr male presents to the ER with pain the in the chest and on further examination it is diagnosed as pericardial effusion, based on this the pain in the pericardium is carried by which nerve
questions.solution:
Nerve Supply of the Pleura The parietal pleura develops from the somatopleuric layer of the lateral plate mesoderm, and is supplied by the somatic nerves. These are the intercostal and phrenic nerves. The parietal pleura is pain sensitive. The costal and peripheral parts of the diaphragmatic pleurae are supplied by the intercostal nerves, and the mediastinal pleura and central part of the diaphragmatic pleurae are supplied by the phrenic nerves (C4)

The pulmonary pleura develops from the splanchnopleuric layer of the lateral plate mesoderm, and is supplied by autonomic nerves. The sympathetic nerves are derived from second to fifth sympathetic ganglia while parasympathetic nerves are drawn from the vagus nerve. This part of the pleura is not sensitive to pain.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 2 THORAX

Chapter 15 THORACIC CAVITY AND PLEURAE page no. 267 and 268

choices.text: Apical segment of right lower lobe
Posterior segment of right upper lobe
Apical segment of left lower lobe
Anterior segment of left upper lobe

questions.text: A 10yr child presents with foreign body lodging, which part of the bronchus is likely to be involved
questions.solution:
Apical segment of right lower lobe is the commonest site of aspiration lung abscess and aspiration preumonia, posterior segment of right upper lobe being the next to get involved. Thus most dependent portion of tung are apical segment of right lower and posterior segment of right upper lobe. Posterior segment of the right upper lobe is the most frequent site of tuberculosis

Anterior, segment of upper lobe is the most frequent site of cancer. Superior segment of lower jobe is related to posterior parts of 4 to 8 cs and can be examined in the triangle of ausculation

Foreign bodies in trachea: Foreign bodies like pins, coins entering the trachea pass into right bronchus; Right bronchus wider shorter, more vertical and is in line with trachea, so the foreign bodies in the trachea travel down into right bronchus and then into posterior basal segments of the lower lobe of the lung

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 2 THORAX Chapter 21 AUTONOMIC NERVOUS SYSTEM, ARTERIES, NERVES AND CLINICAL TERMS page no. 348

questions.text: A 76yr patient with a history of Hypertension presents with chest pain to the ER, the ECG shows signs of Myocardial infarction; which artery can be most commonly involved
questions.solution:
Left anterior descending artery (anterior interventricular) artery is most commonly involved in thrombotic occlusion. This results in infarction of anterior wall of left ventricle, apex of heart and anterior 2/3 of ventricular septum.

Right coronary artery or its posterior interventricular branch is involved most commonly. This results in infarction of inferior/posterior wall of left and right ventricle, posterior 1/3 of ventricular septum. most commonly involved vessel is circumflex coronary artery (branch of LCA). This results in infarction of lateral wall of left ventricle except apex.

  • Left main coronary artery, diagonal branches of LAD artery and marginal branches

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 2 THORAX

Chapter 18 PERICARDIUM AND HEART page no. 306 and 307

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy had mild cough and fever. The physician could feel the increased rate of his pulse, but could not hear the heartbeat on the left side of his chest. After some thought the physician was able. To feel the heart beat as well. Name the congenital anomaly of the heart which could cause inability of heart beat to be felt on the left side
questions.solution:
Apex beat is normally heard in the left fifth intercostal space, 9 cm from midsternal line, within the left lateral line. The congenital anomaly in this case is dextrocardia, when the heart is placed on the right side of the heart. The apex beat is heard in right fifth intercostal space to the right of the inferior end of the sternum.

Normally, the cardiac apex or apex beat is on the left side. In the condition called dextrocardia, the apex is on the right side. Dextrocardia may be part of a condition called situs inversus in which all thoracic and abdominal viscera are a mirror image of normal.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 2 THORAX Chapter 18 PERICARDIUM AND HEART page no. 293 and 294.

questions.text: A Medicine resident is performing a Transesophageal Echo, where will he put the probe to look at the heart
questions.solution:
LA because it forms the base of the heart


The base of the heart is also called its posterior surface. It is formed mainly by the left atrium and by a small part of the right atrium

questions.text: Find the false statement about SA Node
questions.solution:
SA node Is located in the upper part of crista terminalis at the junction of SVC and the right atrium.

It is the pacemakers of the heart and generates impulse at a rate of 70-100/min SA node is suplied by nodal artery, a branch of RCA in 65% cases and a branch of circumflex branch of LCA C in 35% cases

SA node is supplied by right vagus/parasympathetic (inhibitory) and right Sympathetic (excitatory) system as it develops from structures on the right side of embryo.

questions.text: What is shown in the Following X-ray
questions.solution:
The radius commonly gets fractured about 2 cm above its lower end (Colles fracture). This fracture is caused by a fall on the outstretched hand. The distal fragment is displaced upwards and backwards, and the radial styloid process comes to lie proximal to the ulnar styloid process. (It normally lies distal to the ulnar styloid process.) If the distal fragment gets displaced anteriorly, it is called Smith's fracture

A sudden powerful jerk on the hand of a child may dislodge the head of the radius from the grip of the annular ligament. This is known as subluxation of the head of the radias (pulled elbow) The head can normally be felt in a hollow behind the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 1 UPPER LIMB

Chapter 1 BONES page no. 21

questions.text: Following deformity is caused by occlusion of which artery
questions.solution:
The common sites of fracture of humerus are the surgical neck, the shaft, and the supracondylar region.

Supracondylar fracture is common in young age. It is produced by a fall on the outstretched hand. The lower fragment is mostly displaced (backwards so that the elbow is unduly prominent, as in dislocation of the elbow joint. This fracture may cause injury to the median nerve. It may also lead to Volkmann's ischaemic contracture caused by occlusion of the brachial artery

  • The three bony points of the normal elbow form the equilateral triangle in a flexed elbow and are in one line in an extended elbow
  • The humerus has a poor blood supply at the junction of its upper and middle thirds Fractures at this site show delayed union or nonunion.
  • The head of the humerus commonly dislocates inferiorly

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 1 UPPER LIMB

Chapter 1 BONES page no. 17

questions.text: Which of the following is also called Struther's ligament
questions.solution:
Palmaris brevis is a remnant of panniculus carnosus

Third head of coracobrachialis is denoted as struther's ligament

O Rotator cuff consists of supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor and subscapularis Most commonly Tendon damaged among rotators is supraspinatus

questions.text: Which of the following is a branch from the root of the brachial Plexus
questions.solution:
Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 1 UPPER LIMB

Chapter 4 axilla page no. 63

questions.text: Which of the following movement is lost in the given palsy
questions.solution:
Erb's Paralysis

Site of injury: One region of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus is called Erb's point.

Six nerves meet here.

Causes of injury: Undue separation of the head from the shoulder, which is commonly encountered in the following.

  1. Birth injury/difficult childbirth
  2. Fall on the shoulder
  3. During anaesthesia.

Nerve roots involved: Mainly C5 and partly C6.

Muscles paralysed: Mainly biceps brachii, deltoid, brachialis and brachioradialis. Partly supraspinatus, infraspinatus and supinator.

Deformity and position of the limb:

  • Arm: Hangs by the side; it is adducted and medially rotated.
  • Forearm: Extended and pronated.

The deformity is known as 'policeman's tip hand' or waiter's tip hand or 'porter's tip hand'.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 1 UPPER LIMB

Chapter 4 axilla page no. 64

questions.text: Find out the deformity in the following Xray
questions.solution:
Fracture the scaphoid is quite common. The bone fractures through the waist at right angles to its long axis. The fracture is caused by a fall on the outstretched hand, or on the tips of the fingers. This causes tenderness and swelling in the anatomical snuff box, and pain on longitudinal percussion of the thumb and index finger. The residual disability is more marked in the midcarpal joint than in the wrist joint. The importance of the fracture lies in its liability to nonunion, and avascular necrosis of the body of the bone. Normally, the scaphoid has two nutrient arteries, one entering the palmar surface of the tubercle and the other the dorsal surface of the body. Occasionally (13% of cases) both vessels enter through the tubercle or through the distal half of the bone. In such cases, fracture may deprive the proximal half of the bone of its blood supply leading to avascular necrosis

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 1 UPPER LIMB

questions.text: Which of the following movements are unaffected in common peroneal nerve injury
questions.solution:
Ref B D Chaurasia's 8th edition, LL, 176

Common peroneal nerve is the most commonly injured nerve in lower limb. It is closely related to lateral surface of neck of fibula and hence injured in injuries around fibular neck. Clinical features of common

Peroneal nerve injuries are: A) Motor-Foot drop and weakness of ankle dorsiflexion, extension of Toes Due to paralysis of muscles of anterior compartment of leg. Loss of eversion : Due to paralysis of evertors of foot (peroneus longus & peroneus brevis). Plantar flexion and inversion are unaffected which results in 'equinus varus deformity' due to unapposed Action of these muscles. For the same reason, ankle reflex is unaffected

B) Sensory i) Sensory loss along anterior and lateral side of leg, dorsum of foot and toes, including medial side of big toe The lateral border of foot and lateral side of little toe are unaffected (supplied by sural Nerve); and medial border of foot upto ball of big toe is unaffected (supplied by saphenous nerve).

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 1 lower limb

Appendix 1 Nerves, arteries and clinical terms page no. 211 and 212

questions.text: Which peripheral pulse is the most difficult to feel
questions.solution:
Popliteal pulse is the most difficult of the peripheral pulses to feel as it is not as superficial as other palpable arteries and not lies against any bony prominence It lies deep in the popliteal fossa. It is best examined with the subject lying supine or prone, with the knee flexed, in order to relax the tens popliteal fossa. The pulse is then felt by deep pressure over the midline of fossa against the popliteal surface of femur.

questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the Greater sciatic foramen
questions.solution:
1. The piriformis, emerging from the pelvis fills the foramen almost completely. It is the key muscle of the region.
  2. Structures passing above the piriformis are:
    1. Superior gluteal nerve
    2. Superior gluteal vessels
  3. Structures passing below the piriformis are:
    1. Inferior gluteal nerve
    2. Inferior gluteal vessels
    3. Sciatic nerve
    4. Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
    5. Nerve to quadratus femoris
    6. Nerve to obturator internus
    7. Internal pudendal vessels
    8. Pudendal nerve

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 1 lower limb

questions.text: Which of the following is known as policeman of abdomen?
questions.solution:
The greater omentum is a large fold of peritoneum which hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach like an apron and covers the loops of intestines to a varying extent.

Contents -

  1. The right and left gastroepiploic vessels anastomose with each other in the interval between the first two layers of the greater omentum a little below the greater curvature of the stomach.
  2. It also limits the spread of infection by moving to the site of infection and sealing it off from the surrounding areas and also known as the policeman of the abdomen.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Posteriorly: The inferior vena cava, the right suprarenal gland and T12 vertebra.

Superiorly: Caudate process of the liver.

Inferiorly: First part of the duodenum and the horizontal part of the hepatic artery.

questions.text: A 56yr female presents with a swelling in her neck, further examination confirms retrosternal goitre with Pemberton positive, which of the following can be her symptoms
questions.solution:
Compression of mediastinal structures by any tumour gives rise to a group of symptoms known as mediastinal syndrome. The common symptoms are as follows.

  1. Obstruction of superior vena cava gives rise to Engorgement of veins in the upper half of the Body. b. Pressure over the trachea causes dyspnoea, and cough
  2. Pressure on oesophagus causes dysphagia.
  3. Pressure or the left recurrent laryngeal nerve gives rise to hoarseness of voice (dysphonia).
  4. Pressure on the phrenic nerve causes paralysis of the diaphragm on that side.
  5. Pressure on the intercostal nerves gives rise to pain in the area supplied by them. It is called intercostal neuralgia.
  6. Pressure on the vertebral column may cause erosion of the vertebral bodies.

The common causes of mediastinal syndrome are bronchogenic carcinoma, Hodgkin’s disease causing enlargement of the mediastinal lymph nodes, aneurysm or dilatation of the aorta, etc.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 2 thorax

Chapter 17 mediastinum Page no. 287 and 288

questions.text: Find the wrong statement about knee joint
questions.solution:
Locking is produced by continued action of the same muscles that produce extension, i.e. the quadriceps femoris, especially the vastus medialis part.

Unlocking is brought about by the action of the popliteus muscle.

questions.text: A 28yr football player presented with excruciating pain in the knee with the history of getting injured while hitting the football while flexing the knee
questions.solution:
Hyperflexion causes torn meniscus


Injuries to menisci: Strains in a slightly flexed knee, as in kicking a football, the meniscus may get separated from the capsule, or may be torn longitudinally (bucket-handle tear) or transversely.

The medial meniscus is more vulnerable to injury than the lateral because of its fixity to the tibial collateral ligament, and because of greater excursion during rotatory movements. The lateral meniscus is protected by the popliteus which pulls it backwards so that it is not crushed between the articular surfaces.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 1 lower limb

Chapter 12 joints of lower limb Page no. 173

questions.text: A 78yr male presents with Diplopia along with motor loss on right half of the body and right lower half of the face, which of the syndrome can be considered
questions.solution:
A midbrain lesion causing contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral paralysis of the third nerve is known as Weber's syndrome

Brain neuroanatomy

questions.text: A 78yr male patient complained of pain in the inner aspect of right ankle joint and in area of sole, what can be considered according to the age
questions.solution:
The syndrome is called tarsal tunnel syndrome if tibial nerve gets entrapped under the flexor retinaculum of the ankle. Since the tibial nerve gets constricted, there is pain in the sole as the medial and lateral plantar nerves are affected. There may be paralysis of intrinsic muscles of the sole due to compression of medial and lateral plantar nerves

Tarsal tunnel syndrome: The syndrome occurs due to compression of tibial nerve within the fibroosseous tunnel under the flexor retinaculum of ankle joint. This is associated with pain and paraesthesia in the sole of the foot often worse at night.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 1 lower limb Appendix 1 nerves, arteries and clinical terms page no. 212

questions.text: Which of the following structures are penetrated to remove the excess fluid in the following condition
questions.solution:
Hydrocoele is a condition in which fluid accumulates in the processus vaginalis of peritoneum. Some common abnormalities of scrotal content are

1. Tumour of the testis

2. Hydrocoele

3. Epididymitis

4. Varicocoele

5. Spermatocoele

Tapping a hydrocele is a procedure for removing the excess fluid from tunica vaginalis. The layers penetrated by the instrument are:

a. Skin.

b. Dartos muscle and membranous layer of superficial fascia

c. External spermatic fascia.

d. Cremasteric muscle and fascia.

e. Internal spermatic fascia.

f. Parietal layer of tunica vaginalis

questions.solution:
Lateral branches develop from the lateral splanchnic or mesonephric arteries and supply the viscera derived from the intermediate mesoderm.

These are right and left:

  1. Inferior phrenic arteries
  2. Middle suprarenal arteries
  3. Renal arteries
  4. Testicular or ovarian arteries

questions.text: Find the false statement about cisterna chyli
questions.solution:
This is an elongated lymphatic sac, about 5 to 7 cm long. It is situated in front of the first and second lumbar vertebrae, immediately to the right of the abdominal aorta. It is overlapped by the right crus of the diaphragm. Its upper end is continuous with the thoracic duct. It is joined by the right and left lumbar and intestinal lymph trunks.

questions.text: A first year surgery resident while assisting a laprotomy is asked about the structures present beneath the stomach, which of the following structure should he not mention
questions.solution:
The posterior surface of the stomach is related to structures forming the stomach bed, all of which are separated from the stomach by the cavity of the lesser sac.

These structures are:

a. Diaphragm

b. Left kidney

c. Left suprarenal gland

d. Pancreas

e. Transverse mesocolon

f. Splenic flexure of the colon

g. Splenic artery.

Sometimes the spleen is also included in the stomach bed, but it is separated from the stomach by the cavity of the greater sac (and not of the lesser sac).

questions.text: A 56yr alcoholic patient presented with pain in the abdomen, further sonography suggested fluid filled in the Morrison's pouch, which of the following statements are true about the same
questions.solution:
Right posterior subphrenic space or Morrison's pouch is the deepest pouch in lying position.

The intraperitoneal space or pouch between the posterior surface of liver, right kidney and hepatic flexure is called Morrison's or hepatorenal pouch. When a person is lying down, this pouch is the deepest. So pus or fluid tend to gravitate in this pouch.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 abdomen and pelvis

Appendix 2 NERVES, ARTERIES AND CLINICAL TERMS page no. 517

choices.text: Site of maximum tenderness in appendicitis
Junction between lateral one third and medial two thirds of umbilicus and right ASIS

questions.text: Find the false statement about the point shown below
questions.solution:
McBurney's point is the site of maximum tenderness in appendicitis. The point lies at the junction of lateral one-third and medial two-thirds of line joining the right anterior superior iliac spine to umbilicus. It corespond roughly, to the position of the base of the appendix. Examination of a case of acute appendicitis reveals following physical signs.

  1. Hyperaesthesia in the right iliac fossa
  2. Tenderness at McBurney’s point Sens c. Muscle guard and rebound tenderness over the appendix.

When the appendix is retrocaecal, extension of the hip joint may cause pain because the appendix is disturbed by stretching of the psoas major muscle. In pelvic appendicitis pain may be felt when the thigh is flexed and medially rotated, because the obturator internus is stretched.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2, Section 2 abdomen and pelvis, Chapter 20 SMALL AND LARGE INTESTINES page no.  315

questions.text: The sign depicted has diagnostic value for which disease
questions.solution:
Inflammation of the gallbladder is called cholecystitis. The patient complains of pain over the right hypochondrium radiating to the inferior angle of the right scapula, or to right shoulder.

When a finger is placed just below the costal margin, at the tip of the 9th costal cartilage, the patient feels sharp pain on inspiration. He winces with a 'catch' in his breath. This is referred to as Murphy's sign.

Stones may form in the gallbladder. The condition is called cholelithiasis. They typically occur in fat, fertile, female of forty (but also in males). The stones are responsible for the time to time spasmodic pain called biliary colic. In these cases, Murphy's sign is of great diagnostic value

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 abdomen and pelvis

Chapter 22 EXTRAHEPATIC BILIARY APPARATUS page no. 341

questions.text: The broad ligament which is a fold of peritonium contains which of the following
questions.solution:
The broad ligament contains the following structures

  1. The uterine tube
  2. The round ligament of the uterus
  3. The ligament of the ovary
  4. Uterine vessels near its attachment to the uterus
  5. Ovarian vessels in the infundibulopelvic ligament
  6. The uterovaginal and ovarian nerve plexuses
  7. Epoophoron
  8. Paroophoron
  9. Some lymph nodes and lymph vessels
  10. Dense connective tissue or parametrium present on the sides of the uterus

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 abdomen and pelvis

Chapter 31 FEMALE REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS page no. 452

questions.text: Which of the following is not an active or muscular support of uterus ?
questions.solution:
Muscular or active supports

  1. Pelvic diaphragm
  2. Perineal body
  3. Distal urethral sphincter mechanism

Fibromuscular or mechanical supports

  1. Uterine axis
  2. Pubocervical ligaments
  3. Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt
  4. Uterosacral ligaments
  5. Round ligaments of uterus

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 abdomen and pelvis

Chapter 31 FEMALE REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS page no. 453

questions.text: Which of the following are the contents of rectus sheath
questions.solution:
Contents

Muscles -

  1. The rectus abdominis is the chief and largest content.
  2. The pyramidalis (if present) lies in front of the lower part of the rectus abdominis.

Arteries-

  1. The superior epigastric artery
  2. The inferior epigastric artery

Veins-

  1. The superior epigastric vein
  2. The inferior epigastric vein.

Nerves- These are the terminal parts of the lower six thoracic nerves, including the lower five intercostal nerves and the subcostal nerves

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 abdomen and pelvis

Chapter 16 ANTERIOR ABDOMINAL WALL page no. 247

questions.text: A patient presented with complete claw hand and on further investigation the trunk of Brachial plexus was found being compressed which had to be relieved surgically, the surgeon should approach via which triangle
questions.solution:
Supraclavicular Triangle contains Subclavian Artery and Vein along with trunk of Brachial Plexus While Occipital triangle contains dorsal Scapular Nerve, C3-C4 nerves, Occipital Artery

Carotid traingle contains 10/11/12th Cranial nerve along with ICA Posterior triangle has the 11th cranial Nerve

The greater supraclavicular fossa lies above and behind the middle one-third of the clavicle. It overlies the cervical part of the brachial plexus and the third part of the subclavian artery

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 3, Head and neck, Chapter 20 SURFACE MARKING AND RADIOLOGICAL ANATOMY page no. 335

Ref B D Chaurasia’s Anatomy eighted edition
